page.title: 17Historic Buildings.
page.content: The{parish church}of Glastonbury is St. John the Baptist, situated in the High Street, a fine example of perpendicular architecture.The present church was built on Norman foundations in the 15th century. The recently restored tower dates from 1475. {The Tribunal,}also to be found in the High Street, was built sometime after 1400, as courts for the Sheriffs and Justices of the Peace. In earlier times used as a dwelling and a school, today it houses the town museum,mainly displaying relics of the{Lake Village. {The Abbey Barn}is now the home of the {Rural Life Museum.}The Barn was used to store farm produce for some 600 years. Today, it is used to exhibit local rural industry and crafts. {The George and Pilgrim Inn,}was built in 1475 by Abbot Selwood for pilgrims prepared to pay for hospitality.
